headline: CBSE Class 12 Accountancy Exam 2026: Strategy, Pattern, Tips And Tricks For Scoring High Marks
content:
As the Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE) Class 12 board exams are about to start in February 2026, students have begun completing their syllabus to score good marks. All subjects are important, but a few are tougher than others.
Physics, Chemistry, Legal Studies and Accountancy are considered the toughest exams among all. To ensure that the final exam does not come as a surprise, CBSE releases sample papers for all these subjects. Practising these sample papers also reduces exam anxiety and stress.
As everyone knows, Accountancy requires proper revision and concentration. To further reduce stress for students, CBSE has scheduled the Accountancy exam on February 24, 2026, right after Mass Media Studies, which is considered a relatively easy paper.
This year, the Accountancy exam will have 34 questions, and all of them will be compulsory. The question paper will be divided into two parts: A and B. Part A is compulsory for all candidates, while Part B is optional, students must attempt only one of the two options: (i) Analysis of Financial Statements or (ii) Computerised Accounting.

Accountancy is a highly scoring subject if you focus on accuracy, presentation, and practice. You can easily aim for 90+ with these proven strategies:
1. Master the Basics First:Chapters like Partnership Fundamentals and Company Accounts form the foundation. Practise journal entries daily small errors here cost heavy marks in longer questions.
2. Time Management:Allocate 1 hour for MCQs (quick scoring), 1 hour for short-answer questions and 1 hour for long-answer questions. Start with questions you are confident about to build momentum.
3. Workings are Key:Always show clear step-by-step workings for calculations. Even if the final answer is wrong, you can secure up to 50 per cent marks for correct steps.
4. Use Formats Religiously:Prepare Revaluation, Capital, Cash Flow, and other accounts in the exact CBSE-prescribed format with proper rulings and narrations - neat presentation fetches extra marks.
5. Practise Sample Papers & Previous Years:Solve the latest SQP and at least the last 10 years' papers in timed conditions.
6. Handle MCQs Smartly:Read the question and all options twice. Use the elimination method. In assertion-reasoning questions, check whether the reason correctly explains the assertion.
7. Part B Choice:Choose the option you are stronger in.
8. Revision Hacks:Create flashcards for formulas and ratios. Solve 2-3 full-length papers every week under exam conditions.

headline: David Beckham Goes Back To School, Witnesses Hands-On Learning In Andhra Pradesh
content:
Former England football captain and UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador Sir David Beckham made a surprise visit to the Mahatma Jyotiba Phule Andhra Pradesh Backward Classes Welfare Residential School (MJPAPBCWREIS) in Kothavalasa on Wednesday.
During his visit, Beckham observed Project-Based Learning (PBL) in action, an interactive teaching method that encourages students to learn through practical, real-world projects. The initiative is part of a collaborative programme by Mantra4Change and Education Above All, aimed at transforming classrooms across Andhra Pradesh, Bihar, Odisha, and Nagaland.
A post shared by David Beckham (@davidbeckham)
Beckham shared his excitement on Instagram, posting: "Great day in India going back to school supporting Education Above All Foundation's project-based learning initiatives... so much fun."

He joined students on the football field, cheered them on, and watched them engage in classroom activities with enthusiasm. Girl students welcomed him with a dance, showcased handmade musical instruments, planted trees, and participated in football games, reflecting the school's emphasis on holistic learning.
Calling the day "memorable," Beckham expressed his joy at experiencing the students' energy and creativity firsthand, underscoring the impact of innovative teaching methods in India.

headline: Assam Christian Body Raises Concern Over Government Regulating Private School Fees
content:
In a significant development, the Assam Christian Forum (ACF) has expressed concerns over the state government's move to regulate the fee structure of private schools in Assam. This comes after the government, on Tuesday, tabled the Assam Private Educational Institutions (Regulation of Fees) Amendment Bill, 2025, in the state assembly, aimed at tightening the regulation of fees charged by private educational institutions.
ACF, which represents Christian communities across the state, said it is "profoundly alarmed" by the Cabinet's approval of the Bill, asserting that the proposed amendments would strip away long-standing protections for minority-run institutions by enabling "unchecked government control" over their fee structures.
According to the Bill, the new provisions seek to strengthen transparency by ensuring that all non-government educational institutions-including those established and managed by minorities under Article 30(1) of the Constitution-are subject to mandatory registration, fee fixation, and periodic renewal as prescribed by law.
The government has stated that these measures aim to promote equity and affordability in education.

headline: 10 High-Pay Careers That AI Wont Replace Anytime Soon
content:
As Artificial Intelligence (AI) continues to transform industries at an unprecedented pace, concerns are rising over which careers will remain secure in the coming decade. For students planning to study abroad, choosing the right degree has become more important than ever. A new report from willrobotstakemyjob.com (WRTMJ), supported by course pricing data from IDP's database of over 2.5 lakh programmes, evaluates the automation risk, salary prospects and future demand across major occupations. Government labour statistics from Australia, the US, Canada and the UK also inform the study.
Healthcare Leads List Of AI-Safe Jobs
According to the report, the safest careers are those that require intensive human interaction and judgement-primarily in healthcare and medicine. These roles show near-zero automation risk, strong demand and high salaries, making them popular choices for international students.
Among undergraduate-level pathways, physician assistants, nurse practitioners, dentists, physicists, nurse midwives and physical therapists top the list. Physician assistants alone are expected to see 28.5 per cent job growth in the US by 2031, while nurse practitioner roles may rise by 46.3 per cent , one of the fastest expansions in the sector.
Despite the higher cost of studying medicine or dentistry, the payoff is significant: median annual US salaries range from 99,710 dollars for physical therapists to 2,36,000 dollars for urologists and rehabilitation physicians.

Top 10 Overall AI-Safe Jobs (Undergraduate Pathway)
(Key factors: median salary, growth outlook, cost, automation risk)
These roles dominate the highest scoring list due to excellent job prospects, minimal automation risk and strong earning potential.
High-Pay, High-Growth Jobs Requiring Postgraduate Study
The report also highlights careers that remain AI-proof but require postgraduate qualifications. Healthcare again leads with programmes in nursing practice, urology, anesthesiology, neurology, psychiatry, internal medicine and immunology.
Nurse practitioners rank highest, scoring 81.16, driven by rapid hiring needs and a median US salary of $126,260. Similarly, urologists and rehabilitation physicians maintain near-zero automation risk while averaging salaries above $230,000 annually.
Top AI-Safe Careers Requiring PG Degrees
Although postgraduate study increases costs-often adding $30,000 to $80,000-the long-term financial and job security benefits remain unmatched.
Human Skills Offer Biggest Shield Against AI
The report states that roles requiring empathy, complex decision-making and hands-on patient care are the least vulnerable to automation. For students eyeing international degrees, medicine, nursing, psychiatry, immunology and rehabilitation studies offer some of the safest and highest-reward pathways today.
With AI reshaping global workforces, degrees that combine human expertise with professional training are likely to remain in high demand-making healthcare the clear winner in the race for AI-proof careers.

headline: This UK University Invites Applications For Scholarships, Industry-Aligned Programmes
content:
The University of Worcester, a public university in Worcester, United Kingdom, is currently accepting final applications for its January 2026 postgraduate intake, offering scholarships and a range of industry-aligned programmes aimed at preparing students for global careers.
Indian students enrolling for the January 2026 session can access merit-based scholarships of up to 3,000 pounds (Rs 3.52 lakh), along with an additional 500 pounds early payment discount for those who clear their fees in full by January 31, 2026.
Recognised as a finalist for the Times Higher Education University of the Year 2025 award, the University of Worcester continues to focus on student-centred learning, employability and practical training. As part of the upcoming intake, the university is offering programmes such as MBA, MSc International Business Management, MSc Project Management, MSc Logistics and Supply Chain Management, MSc Human Resource Management, and MA Education. Each programme includes a 12-month professional placement to help students gain real-world experience.
Applications for the January 2026 intake will close at the end of November 2025, with the deposit deadline set for December 1, 2025.The university said its emphasis on practical learning is reflected in the Graduate Outcomes Survey 2024, which shows that 96 per cent of Worcester graduates find employment or progress to higher study within 15 months of completing their degree.

"At Worcester, our goal is to prepare graduates who can think critically and work globally," said Nick Slade, Deputy Pro Vice-Chancellor (International and External Affairs).
"Indian students are an essential part of that vision. Their presence enriches our academic community and strengthens the long-standing educational partnership between India and the UK."
Worcester's postgraduate programmes combine academic learning with placements, internships and industry-led projects. Students receive dedicated career guidance, including CV-building sessions, interview preparation and networking opportunities.
For more information about scholarships, course details and the January 2026 admission process, students can visit the university's official website.

headline: Is Kombucha Beneficial For Your Gut Health?
content: Kombucha, a fizzy fermented tea, has emerged as a popular health beverage across the globe. Touted as a natural probiotic, kombucha is often linked to improved digestion, better gut health, and even immune support. Made by fermenting sweetened tea with a symbiotic culture of bacteria and yeast (SCOBY), this ancient drink has been consumed for centuries. But does it really deliver on its health promises, especially for the gut? According to the National Institutes of Health (NIH) and other studies, kombucha may play a supportive role in gut microbiome diversity. Let's explore the science behind this fermented favourite. Kombucha contains natural probiotics and bioactive compounds that may help balance gut bacteria and enhance digestion. During fermentation, beneficial bacteria and organic acids are produced, which can aid the gut microbiome. According to a review published in Frontiers in Microbiology, fermented foods like kombucha can positively influence gut flora, which is essential for nutrient absorption, immune function, and overall digestive well-being. With packed itineraries and limited access to clean facilities, hygiene can often take a back seat. Here are 7 essential hygiene tips to help you stay healthy and safe while travelling. Let's explore why eating a few tulsi leaves every day could be a powerful step toward holistic well-being. The fermentation process produces several strains of live beneficial bacteria, such as Lactobacillus and Acetobacter. These probiotics may help restore the balance of gut flora, especially after antibiotic use or poor dietary habits. A healthy gut microbiome is linked to better digestion, reduced inflammation, and even mental well-being. However, the quantity and strains vary by brand and brew method. Kombucha contains enzymes and organic acids like acetic acid and gluconic acid, which may assist in breaking down food more efficiently. Anecdotal evidence and some early studies suggest that regular consumption of kombucha may alleviate bloating, gas, and indigestion by supporting the body's natural digestive processes. Green or black tea, the base for kombucha, is rich in polyphenols and antioxidants. These compounds can protect the gut lining from oxidative stress and inflammation. Damage to the gut lining is often associated with leaky gut syndrome, food sensitivities, and autoimmune responses, making antioxidant support beneficial for long-term gut health. About 70% of your immune system resides in your gut. A healthy gut microbiome can help modulate immune responses. The probiotics in kombucha may help maintain this balance, reducing your susceptibility to infections and inflammatory responses. While more human clinical trials are needed, the existing data is promising. Gut dysbiosis, or an imbalance in gut microbes, has been linked to several conditions like irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), obesity, and even depression. Regular intake of fermented foods, including kombucha, may help prevent or correct such imbalances. A study in Nutrients (2021) reported that probiotic-rich foods could improve symptoms in individuals with mild digestive disorders. While kombucha is primarily known for probiotics, it may also contain small amounts of prebiotics depending on its ingredients. Prebiotics are plant fibres that feed good bacteria. Ingredients like ginger or fruit add-ins in kombucha may enhance this effect, offering additional gut support. Despite its benefits, kombucha is not suitable for everyone. Unpasteurised kombucha can pose a risk for pregnant women, individuals with weakened immune systems, or those sensitive to caffeine or alcohol. Additionally, many commercial versions contain added sugars, which can negate its health benefits. Always read labels and consult a healthcare provider, especially if you have pre-existing conditions. Kombucha offers potential gut health benefits, largely due to its probiotic content and natural fermentation. While more large-scale human studies are needed, current evidence supports its role as a gut-friendly beverage when consumed in moderation. For optimal results, pair kombucha with a fibre-rich diet and other fermented foods. As always, individual needs vary, consult a doctor before making it a daily habit. headline: 7 Hygiene Tips To Keep In Mind While Travelling
content: Travelling opens up new experiences, but it can also expose you to unfamiliar germs and environments that may affect your health. Whether you're heading to a beach destination, trekking through the hills, or taking a business trip, maintaining personal hygiene is essential to prevent infections, digestive issues, and skin conditions. According to the World Health Organisation (WHO), proper hand hygiene and safe food practices are critical during travel to avoid communicable diseases. With packed itineraries and limited access to clean facilities, hygiene can often take a back seat. Here are 7 essential hygiene tips to help you stay healthy and safe while travelling. Travelling brings increased contact with public surfaces, shared restrooms, and changing food habits, all of which can heighten your risk of infections. From traveller's diarrhoea to respiratory illnesses, poor hygiene can quickly turn a vacation into a visit to the clinic. Being mindful of basic hygiene practices ensures you stay energetic, confident, and illness-free throughout your journey. Let's explore the science behind this fermented favourite. Let's explore why eating a few tulsi leaves every day could be a powerful step toward holistic well-being. Keeping your hands clean is your first line of defence. Always carry an alcohol-based hand sanitiser (at least 60% alcohol) and use it after touching public surfaces, handling money, or before eating. The WHO strongly recommends hand hygiene, especially when soap and water are not available, common while travelling. Trains, flights, and hotel rooms may not always be as clean as they appear. Use disinfectant wipes to clean surfaces such as tray tables, armrests, remote controls, toilet seats, and doorknobs. This reduces the chance of picking up germs left behind by previous users. Your hands touch dozens of surfaces every hour, escalator railings, cab doors, menus, and then may unknowingly transfer germs to your eyes, nose, or mouth. Avoid face-touching as much as possible to reduce the risk of respiratory and skin infections. Food-borne illnesses are common among travellers. Opt for freshly cooked meals and avoid raw, undercooked, or street food if unsure about cleanliness. Drink only bottled or filtered water and avoid ice cubes unless you're certain they're made with purified water. The Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) also recommends avoiding tap water in unfamiliar areas. Public toilets can be unhygienic, especially in remote or high-traffic areas. Carry toilet seat sanitisers, tissue rolls, disposable seat covers, and hand sanitiser. For longer trips, consider including intimate wipes and feminine hygiene products if needed. Maintaining toilet hygiene helps prevent urinary tract infections (UTIs) and skin issues. Sweat and grime accumulate more quickly during travel, especially in humid or hot destinations. Pack clothes made of breathable fabrics like cotton and change them daily. Avoid re-wearing socks or undergarments, as doing so may cause skin irritation or fungal infections. A small laundry bag or detergent sachets can help you keep your garments fresh. Skipping brushing during hectic travel days is common but harmful. Always carry a compact dental kit with a toothbrush, paste, floss, and mouthwash. Good oral hygiene not only prevents bad breath and cavities but also helps reduce the risk of infections that can spread through the bloodstream. Maintaining hygiene while travelling doesn't require complicated routines, it just needs awareness and a little preparation. By following simple yet effective practices, you can protect yourself from illnesses that might disrupt your journey. As travel resumes in full swing post-pandemic, personal hygiene is more crucial than ever. Stay cautious, stay clean, and enjoy a healthy, worry-free travel experience. headline: Health Benefits Of Consuming Raw Tulsi Leaves
content: Tulsi, also known as Holy Basil, is more than just a sacred plant in Indian households, it is a treasure trove of health benefits. For centuries, Ayurvedic medicine has revered tulsi for its therapeutic properties, and modern science now validates many of these claims. Consuming raw tulsi leaves regularly is believed to boost immunity, support respiratory health, improve digestion, and manage stress levels. The Ministry of AYUSH and organisations like the World Health Organisation (WHO) recognise the role of traditional herbs like tulsi in preventive healthcare. Let's explore why eating a few tulsi leaves every day could be a powerful step toward holistic well-being. Tulsi leaves are packed with powerful antioxidants, essential oils, and bioactive compounds like eugenol, ursolic acid, and rosmarinic acid. These natural substances offer anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and adaptogenic effects that can protect your body from various ailments. Consuming the leaves raw ensures maximum potency, as heat or processing may diminish their active components. Let's explore the science behind this fermented favourite. With packed itineraries and limited access to clean facilities, hygiene can often take a back seat. Here are 7 essential hygiene tips to help you stay healthy and safe while travelling. Raw tulsi leaves strengthen the immune system by enhancing the body's ability to fight infections. They stimulate the production of antibodies and have natural antibacterial, antifungal, and antiviral properties. This makes them particularly helpful during seasonal changes or flu outbreaks. Regular consumption can reduce the frequency and severity of colds and fevers. Tulsi acts as a natural decongestant and expectorant, making it effective against respiratory ailments like asthma, bronchitis, and sinusitis. Chewing raw tulsi leaves can help clear phlegm, reduce cough, and ease breathing. Its antimicrobial nature also helps in managing bacterial infections of the respiratory tract. Tulsi is classified as an adaptogen, a natural substance that helps the body cope with physical and emotional stress. According to a study published in the Journal of Ayurveda and Integrative Medicine, tulsi significantly lowers cortisol (the stress hormone) levels and improves mood stability. Chewing raw leaves may help relieve anxiety and promote mental clarity. The compounds in tulsi help balance stomach acids, support healthy gut flora, and relieve digestive issues like bloating, gas, and indigestion. Chewing raw tulsi leaves before or after meals may stimulate digestive enzymes and promote smoother digestion. Tulsi's antibacterial properties make it excellent for oral hygiene. Chewing the leaves can help reduce bad breath, gum infections, and mouth ulcers. It also offers protection against oral pathogens that cause plaque formation and tooth decay. Studies suggest that tulsi may help regulate blood glucose levels, making it beneficial for people with type 2 diabetes. According to research in the International Journal of Clinical Pharmacology and Therapeutics, tulsi can reduce fasting blood sugar and improve insulin sensitivity. Consuming raw leaves in the morning on an empty stomach may help manage sugar levels. Tulsi helps the body flush out toxins by supporting liver and kidney function. It also contains antioxidants that neutralise free radicals and reduce oxidative stress, promoting overall cellular health. Drinking water infused with raw tulsi leaves is a common detox remedy in many Indian households. Raw tulsi leaves are a natural powerhouse offering preventive and therapeutic health benefits. From boosting immunity and aiding digestion to reducing stress and balancing sugar levels, they support overall wellness without side effects. However, moderation is key, consuming 2-3 leaves daily is sufficient. For those seeking natural ways to enhance health, tulsi could be a small but mighty addition to your routine. headline: Natural Detox Remedies For Smokers And Alcoholics
content: Tobacco and alcohol use are two of the most common lifestyle choices that negatively impact the body's vital organs, especially the liver, lungs, heart, and kidneys. While quitting is the best option, the recovery and detoxification process can be supported naturally. Detox doesn't mean extreme fasting or relying on fancy juices, it involves helping the body eliminate toxins through the right foods, hydration, herbs, and lifestyle changes. According to the World Health Organisation (WHO), supporting the body's detoxification systems is essential in substance abuse recovery. Here's how smokers and alcohol users can naturally cleanse their systems and boost their overall health. Alcohol and nicotine leave behind a trail of toxins that accumulate in the liver, lungs, and bloodstream. Over time, these can impair organ function, reduce immunity, and increase the risk of chronic diseases. Natural detox methods can help clear these harmful substances, support organ regeneration, and replenish essential nutrients depleted by prolonged smoking and drinking. Let's explore the science behind this fermented favourite. With packed itineraries and limited access to clean facilities, hygiene can often take a back seat. Here are 7 essential hygiene tips to help you stay healthy and safe while travelling. Water is crucial for flushing out toxins. Aim for at least 810 glasses a day. You can also drink detoxifying liquids like lemon water, coconut water, or cucumber-infused water. For alcoholics, hydration helps rehydrate the body and supports liver function. Smokers benefit as water helps clear tar and toxins from the lungs. Alcohol and cigarette smoke deplete your body of essential antioxidants like vitamin C, E, and beta-carotene. Include berries, citrus fruits, spinach, beetroot, carrots, and tomatoes in your daily diet. These foods help combat oxidative stress and reduce inflammation caused by toxic exposure. Milk thistle is an age-old herbal remedy known to support liver health. The compound silymarin found in milk thistle has antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties that help regenerate liver cells. It's especially beneficial for alcohol-related liver damage. Always consult a doctor before adding supplements to your routine. Smokers can benefit from regular steam inhalation with essential oils like eucalyptus or peppermint to clear lung congestion. Additionally, practicing breathing techniques like pranayama or deep diaphragmatic breathing can improve lung capacity and help expel residual toxins. Green tea is rich in catechins and other antioxidants that help boost liver function and remove toxins. Other herbal teas like dandelion root tea, ginger tea, or turmeric tea support digestion, reduce inflammation, and assist detox pathways. Alcohol irritates the gut lining and alters gut flora, while smoking impacts nutrient absorption. Eating fibre-rich foods like oats, whole grains, flaxseeds, and leafy greens can promote healthy bowel movements and support gut detoxification. A healthy gut also supports immunity and mood regulation. Physical activity increases circulation, boosts metabolism, and promotes sweating, a natural detox pathway. Cardio, brisk walking, or yoga help smokers improve lung function and support alcoholics in liver healing. According to the Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), exercise also helps reduce cravings and improves mental health during recovery. Both smokers and alcohol consumers should reduce intake of processed foods, sugary snacks, and refined carbs. These stress the liver and gut and increase inflammation. Opt instead for clean, home-cooked meals rich in proteins, healthy fats, and whole grains. Quality sleep is the body's natural time for healing. Nicotine and alcohol often disturb sleep cycles, but focusing on 7-8 hours of rest per night helps repair tissues, reset hormones, and support cognitive function during detox. headline: These Abnormalities On Your Hands Suggest These Health Concerns
content: Abnormalities on your hands can sometimes suggest underlying health concerns because the skin, nails, joints, and circulation in your hands are closely linked to internal systems like cardiovascular, nervous, metabolic, and immune functions. Subtle changes in color, texture, swelling, or nail shape can be early indicators of conditions like nutrient deficiencies, thyroid disorders, liver disease, or even autoimmune issues. Since the hands are so vascular and visible, they often show signs of internal imbalances sooner than other parts of the body. In this article, we outline various abnormalities of the hands and what they might indicate to.   Consistently cold hands may indicate poor circulation, low thyroid function (hypothyroidism), or Raynaud's disease, a condition that affects blood flow. If your hands stay cold even in warm conditions, it's worth checking your blood pressure and thyroid levels.  Mild hand tremors could be caused by caffeine or stress, but persistent shaking might be linked to neurological issues like Parkinson's disease or essential tremor. It can also signal thyroid overactivity (hyperthyroidism).  When the tips of the fingers swell and nails curve downward, it may point to oxygen deprivation in the blood, often associated with lung diseases, heart conditions, or even liver issues.  Yellow nails might suggest fungal infections, chronic bronchitis, or lymphedema, while pale nails can indicate anaemia. Bluish nails could mean a lack of oxygen in the blood, possibly related to heart or lung disorders.  Swelling in the fingers that doesn't go away may be due to arthritis, kidney disease, or hormonal imbalances. Inflammation and fluid retention can both be signs of internal stress.  Persistent rashes on the hands can be due to eczema or psoriasis, but they might also be triggered by autoimmune diseases or allergic reactions to medications or foods.  Frequent peeling may signal vitamin B deficiency, especially B3 (niacin) or B7 (biotin), or even dehydration. It can also result from overexposure to harsh soaps and sanitisers, which compromise the skin barrier.  These sensations may suggest nerve compression, such as carpal tunnel syndrome, or more systemic issues like diabetes, which affects nerve health. It could also be a sign of vitamin B12 deficiency.  These could be harmless bruises from trauma, but if unexplained, a dark line under the nail could point to melanoma, a type of skin cancer. It's something that should be evaluated quickly.  A sudden decline in grip strength can be a sign of nerve problems, muscle wasting, or even early rheumatoid arthritis. It can also reflect overall decline in physical health, especially in older adults.  Paying attention to persistent or unusual changes in the hands can help in early detection and timely management of several health conditions. headline: These Supplements May Be Harming Your Kidneys
content: Supplements can be harmful to the kidneys, especially when taken in excess or without proper medical guidance. The kidneys are responsible for filtering waste and toxins from the blood, and certain supplements can overburden this system, leading to damage or worsening existing kidney conditions. Some supplements contain substances that are directly toxic to the kidneys, while others can interfere with medications, alter fluid and electrolyte balance, or contribute to the formation of kidney stones. Read on as we share a list of supplements that might be harming your kidneys.   Vitamin D is essential for bone health and immune function, but excessive intake can raise calcium levels in the blood. This condition, called hypercalcemia, can strain the kidneys and lead to the formation of calcium-based kidney stones. Prolonged high calcium levels may also cause calcification in kidney tissues, impairing their function.  Common among athletes and bodybuilders, creatine is used to enhance muscle performance. However, high doses or prolonged use can stress the kidneys by increasing the amount of creatinine, a waste product that kidneys must filter. In people with existing kidney conditions, creatine can accelerate damage.  Protein is essential, but overconsumption especially through supplements can overwork the kidneys. Excess protein increases the nitrogen load in the blood, which the kidneys must excrete. This can lead to glomerular hyper-filtration and, over time, may contribute to kidney damage, especially in people with underlying kidney disease.  Willow bark and similar herbal supplements contain salicylates, similar to aspirin and other non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). These can reduce blood flow to the kidneys and interfere with their ability to regulate salt and water balance, potentially leading to acute kidney injury, especially when used frequently or in combination with dehydration.  While vitamin C is water-soluble and generally considered safe, large doses (over 2,000 mg/day) can increase oxalate production in the body. Oxalate can bind with calcium to form crystals, which may accumulate in the kidneys as stones. Chronic overuse of vitamin C supplements has been linked to oxalate nephropathy, a serious kidney condition.  Used for digestive issues and adrenal fatigue, licorice root contains glycyrrhizin, which can lead to elevated blood pressure and low potassium levels, a condition known as hypokalaemia. These effects can strain kidney function, especially in people with pre-existing heart or kidney conditions. Chronic use has been associated with fluid retention and electrolyte imbalances that impair renal health.  While magnesium is vital for muscle and nerve function, taking too much, especially in supplement form can be harmful, particularly in people with reduced kidney function. Healthy kidneys usually excrete excess magnesium, but when they are impaired, magnesium can accumulate in the body, causing symptoms like nausea, low blood pressure, and, in severe cases, kidney toxicity or even cardiac arrest.  Even healthy individuals may be at risk if they use high doses over a prolonged period or combine multiple supplements without supervision. headline: 7 Long-Term Health Risks Of Ultra-Processed Foods
content: Ultra-processed foods, those high in artificial additives, refined sugars, saturated fats, and preservatives, have become a convenient part of modern diets. From packaged snacks to sugary drinks, these foods are everywhere. However, the long-term health consequences are alarming. According to a 2023 report by the World Health Organisation (WHO), diets rich in ultra-processed foods are linked to a range of chronic conditions including obesity, type 2 diabetes, and heart disease. The issue isn't just about empty calories, it's about the chemical processing that strips food of its natural nutritional value and may harm your body over time. Here's what you need to know. Ultra-processed foods often contain high levels of sugar, unhealthy fats, sodium, and chemical additives that can disrupt metabolic health. They are designed for shelf life and taste, not nutrition. As per Harvard Health and WHO, consistent consumption of such foods can trigger inflammation, hormone imbalance, and poor gut health, increasing your risk of lifestyle diseases and even some cancers over time. Let's explore the science behind this fermented favourite. With packed itineraries and limited access to clean facilities, hygiene can often take a back seat. Here are 7 essential hygiene tips to help you stay healthy and safe while travelling. Ultra-processed foods are calorie-dense and nutrient-poor. They promote overeating due to their addictive combinations of sugar, salt, and fat. These foods also bypass normal satiety signals, leading to weight gain. A study published in Cell Metabolism (2019) found that people who ate ultra-processed foods consumed 500 more calories daily compared to those eating whole foods, significantly increasing their risk of obesity. The high glycemic index of ultra-processed foods spikes blood sugar levels rapidly. Over time, this can lead to insulin resistance and eventually type 2 diabetes. The British Medical Journal (BMJ) published findings indicating a 12% higher risk of diabetes among individuals who frequently consumed ultra-processed items, including sugary drinks, refined cereals, and packaged desserts. High sodium and trans fat content in ultra-processed foods can elevate blood pressure and cholesterol levels. This significantly increases the risk of cardiovascular diseases. The American Heart Association warns that even moderate consumption of these foods may contribute to arterial plaque buildup and hypertension, particularly in middle-aged adults. Emerging evidence links frequent intake of ultra-processed foods to an elevated cancer risk. A French study in The BMJ found that a 10% increase in ultra-processed food consumption was associated with a 12% higher risk of cancer. Additives like emulsifiers, nitrates, and artificial sweeteners may disrupt gut microbiota and promote carcinogenic activity. Ultra-processed foods are low in fibre and high in chemical additives that can damage the gut lining. They disturb the natural balance of healthy bacteria, leading to issues like bloating, constipation, or even inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD). A healthy gut is vital for immune and mental health, and long-term exposure to these foods can compromise both. Research suggests a correlation between ultra-processed food consumption and mood disorders such as depression and anxiety. A study in Public Health Nutrition linked these diets with a 30% increase in the likelihood of experiencing depression. These foods lack essential nutrients like B-vitamins and omega-3 fatty acids, which support brain function. A large-scale Spanish cohort study concluded that those who consumed more than four servings of ultra-processed foods per day had a 62% higher risk of all-cause mortality. Regular intake of these foods affects multiple systems in the body, metabolic, cardiovascular, and immune, leading to accelerated aging and disease vulnerability. Ultra-processed foods may offer convenience, but the long-term health risks are far too significant to ignore. From metabolic dysfunction to increased cancer and mortality risks, their impact spans the entire body. Reducing intake and choosing whole, minimally processed foods can drastically improve overall health. As always, consult your doctor or a dietitian for personalised dietary guidance. Reducing stress not only improves mood but also enhances reproductive hormone function and sexual health. Routine visits to a gynaecologist (for women) or andrologist/urologist (for men) help identify issues early. Fertility tests, hormone panels, and pelvic exams can catch concerns before they escalate. a. Women should get regular Pap smears, HPV tests, and monitor menstrual irregularities. b. Men can benefit from semen analysis and testosterone level assessments if facing fertility issues. c. Timely intervention can treat or reverse many causes of infertility and improve long-term reproductive health. Reproductive health is not just about reproduction, it's about maintaining hormonal balance, physical well-being, and emotional stability. headline: Here's What Your Earwax Reveals About Health
content: Earwax, technically known as cerumen, might seem like an unpleasant byproduct of the body, but it serves several important functions. It traps dust, bacteria, and foreign particles, keeping the inner ear clean and protected. Surprisingly, its colour, texture, and amount can offer insights into your overall health. From infections to genetic markers, earwax may act as an early warning sign for certain conditions. According to the American Academy of Otolaryngology, earwax is a natural self-cleaning agent and a key indicator of ear health. Paying attention to changes in earwax could help detect potential issues before they become serious. Earwax isn't just about hygiene, it reflects what's happening inside your body. Variations in its colour, texture, or odour can point toward infections, stress, metabolic conditions, and even inherited traits. Understanding these subtle shifts can help you better monitor your ear and general health. Let's take a closer look at what different types of earwax may reveal. Let's explore the science behind this fermented favourite. With packed itineraries and limited access to clean facilities, hygiene can often take a back seat. Here are 7 essential hygiene tips to help you stay healthy and safe while travelling. One of the most basic distinctions in earwax is whether it's dry (grey and flaky) or wet (yellow to brown and sticky). This is determined by a single gene, ABCC11. Most East Asians have dry earwax, while people of African or European descent generally have the wet type. While this difference is harmless, it may also be associated with body odour tendencies. This is the most common colour and texture of earwax in children and young adults. It's sticky and traps debris efficiently. This type usually indicates a healthy, functioning ear canal. If you notice this and there are no symptoms like pain or hearing loss, there's likely no cause for concern. Dark-coloured earwax is often a sign of older cerumen that has collected dust or debris. However, very dark or black earwax can also be linked to oxidative stress, which may result from anxiety or environmental factors. Unless accompanied by discomfort or odour, it's generally harmless, but worth monitoring if it happens frequently. Earwax that appears white and flaky may suggest an underlying skin condition such as eczema or psoriasis, especially if there is associated itching or scaling near the ear canal. People with these conditions are also more prone to wax build-up and blockages. If your earwax is green or has a bad odour, it could indicate a bacterial infection in the ear canal. This may be accompanied by symptoms like pain, fluid discharge, or hearing issues. According to the National Institutes of Health (NIH), foul-smelling earwax is often an early sign of otitis externa or swimmer's ear. Thin, watery wax, especially if accompanied by popping sounds or ear pressure, may suggest fluid behind the eardrum, a symptom common in ear infections or sinus issues. This is particularly frequent in children and can impact hearing if untreated. If your earwax is tinged with blood, it might signal a scratch, ruptured eardrum, or even more serious issues like a tumour or chronic infection. The Mayo Clinic recommends consulting an ENT specialist if you notice blood in earwax, especially if paired with hearing loss or dizziness. Earwax is more than just an ear-cleaning mechanism, it can be a useful indicator of your inner health. By observing changes in texture, colour, and smell, you can detect early warning signs of infections, skin disorders, or even genetic traits. If in doubt, consult a medical professional rather than self-cleaning with cotton buds, which may worsen the issue.   Disclaimer: This content including advice provides generic information only. headline: Can Excessive Salt Intake Affect Your Mental Health?
content: Salt is an essential part of our diet, helping maintain fluid balance, support nerve function, and regulate blood pressure. From increased anxiety to cognitive impairment, the effect of salt on the brain is becoming a growing concern. According to the World Health Organisation (WHO), reducing salt intake is crucial not just for heart health, but for overall well-being. Your brain is highly sensitive to chemical changes in the body. Consuming too much salt may affect hormones, blood pressure, and inflammation, each of which can impact your mental health. Research is emerging that suggests a high-sodium diet could worsen symptoms of depression, anxiety, and even increase the risk of neurodegenerative diseases. Too much salt can lead to hypertension, which narrows blood vessels and restricts blood flow to the brain. Over time, this can cause cognitive decline, memory issues, and may even contribute to the development of dementia. The American Heart Association warns that uncontrolled blood pressure is a silent but significant contributor to brain damage. A high-salt diet can disrupt the gut microbiota, which in turn affects the gut-brain axisa communication pathway between your digestive tract and brain. According to research from the National Institutes of Health (NIH), the gut microbiome plays a critical role in regulating mood and mental clarity. Salt influences the body's hormonal balance. Emerging research has shown that excessive salt intake could accelerate the risk of Alzheimer's disease. A 2020 study published in Cell suggested that high salt disrupts nitric oxide production, a compound essential for healthy blood vessels in the brain. Reduced nitric oxide impairs brain function and is associated with neurodegenerative conditions. People consuming high-sodium diets are more prone to experiencing mood fluctuations. Though the evidence is still evolving, studies from the Journal of Clinical Psychiatry note a possible correlation between high salt diets and an increased prevalence of depressive symptoms. While salt is vital in moderation, excessive intake poses serious risks beyond physical health, it can compromise brain function and mental well-being. Experts from the WHO recommend keeping salt intake under 5 grams per day. Reducing processed foods and choosing fresh, whole ingredients is a practical first step toward safeguarding both your heart and your mind. headline: These Habits Can Be Beneficial For Women Struggling With Fertility
content: Lifestyle habits can be highly beneficial for fertility in women. While underlying medical conditions can contribute to fertility challenges, many women can improve their chances of conceiving by making intentional changes to their daily routines. Habits related to nutrition, stress management, sleep, physical activity, and exposure to environmental toxins all influence hormonal balance, ovulation, and overall reproductive health. Making healthy lifestyle choices can help increase your chances of conceiving. Keep reading as we share a list of habits you can adopt to boost your fertility.  In this article, we share tips that can help boost fertility in men during summer. Several studies suggest that day-to-day stress in women can lower the chances of getting pregnant.  Both being underweight and overweight can disrupt ovulation and hormone levels, which are essential for fertility. Excess fat can lead to higher oestrogen levels, while too little body fat can prevent menstruation altogether.  A diet rich in whole foods especially leafy greens, berries, whole grains, legumes, healthy fats, and lean proteins can provide essential nutrients like folate, iron, zinc, and antioxidants. These nutrients support hormone regulation, egg quality, and reduce inflammation, all of which are crucial for reproductive health.  Chronic stress can disrupt the delicate hormonal balance needed for ovulation and menstruation. Practices like yoga, meditation, deep breathing, or even hobbies and social time can help lower cortisol levels and create a more fertile internal environment.  High consumption of alcohol and caffeine has been linked to reduced fertility. While moderate caffeine (around 1 cup of coffee per day) is generally safe, limiting or avoiding alcohol altogether is advised for those trying to conceive, as it can interfere with hormone levels and egg quality.  Smoking harms reproductive health by accelerating egg loss and damaging the fallopian tubes. It also affects hormonal balance and may lead to early menopause. Avoiding all forms of tobacco and minimising exposure to secondhand smoke is vital for women trying to conceive.  Poor sleep affects hormone regulation, including the hormones responsible for ovulation. Aim for 79 hours of uninterrupted, restful sleep each night to support reproductive health and balance stress levels, both of which are key to fertility.  While regular physical activity helps maintain a healthy weight and reduce stress, overexercising can disrupt menstruation and ovulation. Moderate-intensity workouts like walking, swimming, or yoga are beneficial, while extreme endurance routines may harm fertility.  Understanding your menstrual cycle and recognising fertile windows can greatly increase the chance of conception. Using ovulation predictor kits, tracking basal body temperature, or paying attention to cervical mucus changes can help time intercourse more effectively.  Everyday chemicals found in plastics, cosmetics, cleaning products, and pesticides can act as endocrine disruptors. Reducing exposure to these by choosing natural or organic products and avoiding BPA-containing plastics can help protect hormonal balance and fertility.  Regular visits to a gynaecologist or fertility specialist can help catch and manage any medical issues like thyroid imbalances, polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), or endometriosis that may impact fertility. Early detection and treatment are key to improving reproductive outcomes.  Adopting fertility-friendly habits can not only support natural conception but also enhance the effectiveness of medical fertility treatments. headline: These Supplements Can Help Reduce Brain Fog
content: Brain fog is a non-medical term used to describe a state of mental fatigue or clouded thinking, where a person may struggle with concentration, memory, mental clarity, and alertness. headline: 7 Biotin-Rich Foods For A Healthy Pregnancy
content: Biotin, also known as vitamin B7, is a water-soluble B-complex vitamin that plays a crucial role during pregnancy. headline: What Is Parasomnia In Children?
content: Sleep plays a vital role in a child's physical and mental development. However, certain sleep disorders like parasomnia can interrupt this essential rest. Parasomnia refers to unusual behaviours or experiences during sleep, including sleepwalking, night terrors, talking during sleep, or waking up confused. These disturbances, though often harmless, can be alarming for parents and caregivers. According to the American Academy of Sleep Medicine (AASM), parasomnias are more prevalent in children than adults and usually occur during transitions between sleep stages. Early awareness and management can ensure better sleep hygiene and reduce risks associated with parasomnias in growing children. Parasomnias in children are typically classified into non-REM (NREM) and REM-related disorders. They can range from mild to severe, and while most children outgrow them, persistent symptoms may need medical attention. Here are the common types of parasomnias in children. Let's explore the science behind this fermented favourite. With packed itineraries and limited access to clean facilities, hygiene can often take a back seat. Here are 7 essential hygiene tips to help you stay healthy and safe while travelling. One of the most well-known parasomnias, sleepwalking involves a child moving around while still asleep. It usually occurs in deep NREM sleep and may involve aimless walking or attempts to leave the house. Safety precautions are essential. Unlike nightmares, night terrors cause a child to scream, sweat, and appear terrified, often with open eyes, but they won't be awake or responsive. These episodes typically occur early in the night and the child has no memory of them. Children experiencing this may wake up confused, disoriented, or upset. They might mumble or thrash around, but not be fully awake. These episodes usually happen during deep sleep and subside on their own. Common and usually harmless, sleep talking involves mumbling or even complete sentences during sleep. It's often triggered by stress, fever, or lack of sleep. Unlike night terrors, nightmares occur during REM sleep and are vividly remembered. If frequent, they may indicate emotional stress or trauma and can disrupt sleep quality. Although rare in children, sleep paralysis involves temporary inability to move or speak upon waking. It can be frightening but is usually harmless and linked to poor sleep cycles. Though often not classified strictly as parasomnia, persistent bedwetting in older children may coincide with other sleep disturbances and needs evaluation if it continues beyond the typical age. According to the National Sleep Foundation, common parasomnias include sleepwalking, night terrors, confusional arousals, and nightmares, often influenced by stress, fever, or irregular sleep schedules. A family history of parasomnias increases the likelihood in children. Irregular sleep routines and insufficient rest can trigger episodes. Emotional disturbances or trauma can contribute to nightmares and sleepwalking. High temperatures can increase the frequency of night terrors. Some drugs affecting the nervous system may induce parasomnias. Sudden noise or light changes during sleep can trigger abnormal sleep behaviours. Always consult a paediatrician if symptoms persist, worsen, or impact daytime functioning, early intervention can make all the difference in a child's wellbeing. Ensure regular bedtime and wake-up times. Avoid screens, loud noises, and caffeine before bed. These can reduce fear associated with night terrors or nightmares. Help children express emotions and reduce anxiety through play or therapy. Lock doors and windows, remove obstacles, and avoid bunk beds for sleepwalkers. If parasomnias are frequent or disruptive, a medical evaluation is advised. Parasomnia in children, while concerning for parents, is often a temporary phase that resolves with time and proper sleep hygiene. Understanding the types, triggers, and management strategies can provide reassurance and improve a child's sleep quality. headline: 7 Common Triggers Of Migraine In Summers
content: For migraine sufferers, summer isn't always sunshine and happiness. Rising temperatures, intense humidity, and shifting routines can all become silent triggers. According to the World Health Organisation (WHO) and studies published by the American Migraine Foundation, environmental factors such as heat, dehydration, and bright light can exacerbate migraine episodes, particularly in warmer months. Understanding these seasonal triggers is essential for individuals who experience recurrent migraine attacks. By identifying and avoiding specific summer-related stimuli, people can reduce both the frequency and severity of migraines, leading to better control and an improved quality of life during the hottest months of the year. Summer heat can influence neurological and vascular systems, increasing the risk of migraines. Sudden weather changes, sun exposure, and poor hydration may lead to dilated blood vessels, a known contributor to migraines. According to the National Headache Foundation, these environmental factors often intensify the condition. Recognising these patterns is the first step toward prevention and effective migraine management. These are the most common triggers of migraine in summers. Let's explore the science behind this fermented favourite. With packed itineraries and limited access to clean facilities, hygiene can often take a back seat. Here are 7 essential hygiene tips to help you stay healthy and safe while travelling. Sweating more in the heat without replenishing fluids can lead to dehydration, a top migraine trigger. Even mild dehydration can cause headaches. Always carry water, and increase intake of fluids, especially when outdoors. Bright sunlight and high UV rays can overstimulate the brain's visual cortex. Prolonged exposure can lead to photophobia (light sensitivity) and trigger migraines. Sunglasses, wide-brimmed hats, and limiting time outdoors during peak hours are essential. High temperatures combined with humidity can cause your body to overheat, disturbing internal temperature regulation and increasing the risk of migraine. Stay in cool environments and use fans or air-conditioning to reduce impact. Summer routines often lead to irregular eating. Skipping meals causes blood sugar levels to drop, a common migraine trigger. Eat light but balanced meals every 3-4 hours to maintain energy and avoid crashes. Longer days can disrupt the body's sleep-wake cycle, especially if you're staying up late or waking earlier. Poor or irregular sleep is directly linked to migraine episodes. Aim for 7-9 hours of quality sleep daily. Cold coffees, sodas, and energy drinks may seem refreshing but often contain caffeine and sugar, both of which can aggravate migraines. Sudden intake or withdrawal from caffeine can also contribute to headaches. Summer often brings stronger odours, perfumes, sweat, pesticides, or chlorinated pool water, all of which can trigger migraines in sensitive individuals. Also, increased pollen and pollution can worsen sinus inflammation, another migraine pathway. Simple changes like staying hydrated, regulating sleep, and protecting yourself from extreme heat and sunlight go a long way. With vigilance and preventive care, those prone to migraines can enjoy a more comfortable and pain-free summer season. 1. Maintain a migraine diary to track specific seasonal triggers 2. Use cooling face towels and stay indoors during high-heat hours (12-4 pm) 3. Eat hydrating foods like cucumbers, watermelon, and yoghurt 4. Avoid sudden exposure to air conditioning after extreme heat 5. Keep sunglasses and an umbrella handy when outdoors 6. Limit screen time to avoid light-triggered headaches 7. Try relaxation techniques like meditation or breathing exercises to reduce stress While migraines can feel unpredictable, recognising and managing summer-specific triggers can make a substantial difference. When in doubt, always consult a healthcare provider for personalised guidance.   Disclaimer: This content including advice provides generic information only. headline: 7 High Glycemic Foods Diabetics Should Avoid
content: Managing diabetes effectively requires more than just medication, it hinges heavily on dietary choices. One of the most important factors in diabetic nutrition is the glycemic index (GI) of foods. The World Health Organisation (WHO) and the American Diabetes Association (ADA) both highlight the importance of avoiding high-GI foods, as they can cause rapid spikes in blood glucose levels. These foods are quickly broken down into sugar, which makes them risky for people with type 2 or type 1 diabetes. Being aware of high-GI foods and replacing them with healthier alternatives is key to keeping blood sugar levels stable and avoiding complications. The glycemic index ranks carbohydrates from 0 to 100 based on how fast they raise blood sugar. High-GI foods (above 70) cause sharp increases in glucose, leading to insulin spikes. Over time, this can worsen insulin resistance and increase the risk of complications. Monitoring GI can help diabetics maintain stable sugar levels and support long-term metabolic health. Here are mentioned 7 high glycemic foods diabetics should avoid. Let's explore the science behind this fermented favourite. With packed itineraries and limited access to clean facilities, hygiene can often take a back seat. Here are 7 essential hygiene tips to help you stay healthy and safe while travelling. Made from refined flour, white bread has a GI of around 75. It lacks fibre and nutrients, leading to a fast release of sugar into the bloodstream. Opt for wholegrain or multigrain bread instead. Cornflakes and puffed rice cereals may seem convenient, but they are among the highest GI foods (GI 80+). Choose high-fibre oats or unsweetened muesli to prevent sugar spikes after breakfast. Polished white rice, especially when overcooked, has a GI above 70. It can significantly raise post-meal glucose levels. Brown rice, quinoa, or millets like bajra or jowar are much healthier alternatives for Indian diets. Potatoes have a naturally high starch content. Mashed potatoes, with a GI of 85 or more, are especially problematic. Sweet potatoes or boiled potatoes in moderation with fibre-rich meals may be safer. These are loaded with added sugars and lack fibre, causing an immediate sugar surge. Their GI is often above 75. Diabetics should stick to water, unsweetened herbal teas, or diluted fresh lemon water. Refined pasta is quickly digested and converted into glucose. It ranks high on the GI scale unless paired with fibre and protein. Whole wheat pasta or zucchini noodles offer better glycemic control. While nutritious, watermelon has a GI of 76. Though its glycemic load is moderate due to high water content, large servings can still cause a sugar spike. Limit portion size and balance with protein. Replacing these items with low-GI, nutrient-rich alternatives is a simple yet powerful step toward better health and a more balanced lifestyle. 1. Combine high GI items with protein or fibre to slow glucose absorption. 2. Avoid cooking starchy foods for too long, as this increases their GI. 3. Use the plate method: half veggies, one-quarter protein, and one-quarter whole grain. 4. Keep a food diary to track reactions to specific foods. Understanding and managing the glycemic index of your diet is crucial for diabetes care. By avoiding or limiting these high-GI foods, diabetics can maintain more consistent blood sugar levels and reduce the risk of long-term complications. headline: Is Kombucha Beneficial For Your Gut Health?
content: Kombucha, a fizzy fermented tea, has emerged as a popular health beverage across the globe. Touted as a natural probiotic, kombucha is often linked to improved digestion, better gut health, and even immune support. Made by fermenting sweetened tea with a symbiotic culture of bacteria and yeast (SCOBY), this ancient drink has been consumed for centuries. But does it really deliver on its health promises, especially for the gut? According to the National Institutes of Health (NIH) and other studies, kombucha may play a supportive role in gut microbiome diversity. Let's explore the science behind this fermented favourite. Kombucha contains natural probiotics and bioactive compounds that may help balance gut bacteria and enhance digestion. During fermentation, beneficial bacteria and organic acids are produced, which can aid the gut microbiome. According to a review published in Frontiers in Microbiology, fermented foods like kombucha can positively influence gut flora, which is essential for nutrient absorption, immune function, and overall digestive well-being. With packed itineraries and limited access to clean facilities, hygiene can often take a back seat. Here are 7 essential hygiene tips to help you stay healthy and safe while travelling. Let's explore why eating a few tulsi leaves every day could be a powerful step toward holistic well-being. The fermentation process produces several strains of live beneficial bacteria, such as Lactobacillus and Acetobacter. These probiotics may help restore the balance of gut flora, especially after antibiotic use or poor dietary habits. A healthy gut microbiome is linked to better digestion, reduced inflammation, and even mental well-being. However, the quantity and strains vary by brand and brew method. Kombucha contains enzymes and organic acids like acetic acid and gluconic acid, which may assist in breaking down food more efficiently. Anecdotal evidence and some early studies suggest that regular consumption of kombucha may alleviate bloating, gas, and indigestion by supporting the body's natural digestive processes. Green or black tea, the base for kombucha, is rich in polyphenols and antioxidants. These compounds can protect the gut lining from oxidative stress and inflammation. Damage to the gut lining is often associated with leaky gut syndrome, food sensitivities, and autoimmune responses, making antioxidant support beneficial for long-term gut health. About 70% of your immune system resides in your gut. A healthy gut microbiome can help modulate immune responses. The probiotics in kombucha may help maintain this balance, reducing your susceptibility to infections and inflammatory responses. While more human clinical trials are needed, the existing data is promising. Gut dysbiosis, or an imbalance in gut microbes, has been linked to several conditions like irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), obesity, and even depression. Regular intake of fermented foods, including kombucha, may help prevent or correct such imbalances. A study in Nutrients (2021) reported that probiotic-rich foods could improve symptoms in individuals with mild digestive disorders. While kombucha is primarily known for probiotics, it may also contain small amounts of prebiotics depending on its ingredients. Prebiotics are plant fibres that feed good bacteria. Ingredients like ginger or fruit add-ins in kombucha may enhance this effect, offering additional gut support. Despite its benefits, kombucha is not suitable for everyone. Unpasteurised kombucha can pose a risk for pregnant women, individuals with weakened immune systems, or those sensitive to caffeine or alcohol. Additionally, many commercial versions contain added sugars, which can negate its health benefits. Always read labels and consult a healthcare provider, especially if you have pre-existing conditions. Kombucha offers potential gut health benefits, largely due to its probiotic content and natural fermentation. While more large-scale human studies are needed, current evidence supports its role as a gut-friendly beverage when consumed in moderation. For optimal results, pair kombucha with a fibre-rich diet and other fermented foods. As always, individual needs vary, consult a doctor before making it a daily habit. headline: 7 Hygiene Tips To Keep In Mind While Travelling
content: Travelling opens up new experiences, but it can also expose you to unfamiliar germs and environments that may affect your health. According to the World Health Organisation (WHO), proper hand hygiene and safe food practices are critical during travel to avoid communicable diseases. With packed itineraries and limited access to clean facilities, hygiene can often take a back seat. Here are 7 essential hygiene tips to help you stay healthy and safe while travelling. Travelling brings increased contact with public surfaces, shared restrooms, and changing food habits, all of which can heighten your risk of infections. From traveller's diarrhoea to respiratory illnesses, poor hygiene can quickly turn a vacation into a visit to the clinic. Always carry an alcohol-based hand sanitiser (at least 60% alcohol) and use it after touching public surfaces, handling money, or before eating. The WHO strongly recommends hand hygiene, especially when soap and water are not available, common while travelling. Trains, flights, and hotel rooms may not always be as clean as they appear. Use disinfectant wipes to clean surfaces such as tray tables, armrests, remote controls, toilet seats, and doorknobs. This reduces the chance of picking up germs left behind by previous users. Your hands touch dozens of surfaces every hour, escalator railings, cab doors, menus, and then may unknowingly transfer germs to your eyes, nose, or mouth. Avoid face-touching as much as possible to reduce the risk of respiratory and skin infections. Food-borne illnesses are common among travellers. Opt for freshly cooked meals and avoid raw, undercooked, or street food if unsure about cleanliness. Drink only bottled or filtered water and avoid ice cubes unless you're certain they're made with purified water. The Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) also recommends avoiding tap water in unfamiliar areas. Public toilets can be unhygienic, especially in remote or high-traffic areas. Carry toilet seat sanitisers, tissue rolls, disposable seat covers, and hand sanitiser. For longer trips, consider including intimate wipes and feminine hygiene products if needed. Maintaining toilet hygiene helps prevent urinary tract infections (UTIs) and skin issues. Sweat and grime accumulate more quickly during travel, especially in humid or hot destinations. Pack clothes made of breathable fabrics like cotton and change them daily. Avoid re-wearing socks or undergarments, as doing so may cause skin irritation or fungal infections. A small laundry bag or detergent sachets can help you keep your garments fresh. Skipping brushing during hectic travel days is common but harmful. Always carry a compact dental kit with a toothbrush, paste, floss, and mouthwash. Good oral hygiene not only prevents bad breath and cavities but also helps reduce the risk of infections that can spread through the bloodstream. Maintaining hygiene while travelling doesn't require complicated routines, it just needs awareness and a little preparation. By following simple yet effective practices, you can protect yourself from illnesses that might disrupt your journey. As travel resumes in full swing post-pandemic, personal hygiene is more crucial than ever. Stay cautious, stay clean, and enjoy a healthy, worry-free travel experience. headline: These Abnormalities On Your Hands Suggest These Health Concerns
content: Abnormalities on your hands can sometimes suggest underlying health concerns because the skin, nails, joints, and circulation in your hands are closely linked to internal systems like cardiovascular, nervous, metabolic, and immune functions. Subtle changes in color, texture, swelling, or nail shape can be early indicators of conditions like nutrient deficiencies, thyroid disorders, liver disease, or even autoimmune issues. Since the hands are so vascular and visible, they often show signs of internal imbalances sooner than other parts of the body. In this article, we outline various abnormalities of the hands and what they might indicate to.   Consistently cold hands may indicate poor circulation, low thyroid function (hypothyroidism), or Raynaud's disease, a condition that affects blood flow. If your hands stay cold even in warm conditions, it's worth checking your blood pressure and thyroid levels.  Mild hand tremors could be caused by caffeine or stress, but persistent shaking might be linked to neurological issues like Parkinson's disease or essential tremor. It can also signal thyroid overactivity (hyperthyroidism).  When the tips of the fingers swell and nails curve downward, it may point to oxygen deprivation in the blood, often associated with lung diseases, heart conditions, or even liver issues.  Yellow nails might suggest fungal infections, chronic bronchitis, or lymphedema, while pale nails can indicate anaemia. Bluish nails could mean a lack of oxygen in the blood, possibly related to heart or lung disorders.  Swelling in the fingers that doesn't go away may be due to arthritis, kidney disease, or hormonal imbalances. Inflammation and fluid retention can both be signs of internal stress.  Persistent rashes on the hands can be due to eczema or psoriasis, but they might also be triggered by autoimmune diseases or allergic reactions to medications or foods.  Frequent peeling may signal vitamin B deficiency, especially B3 (niacin) or B7 (biotin), or even dehydration. It can also result from overexposure to harsh soaps and sanitisers, which compromise the skin barrier.  These sensations may suggest nerve compression, such as carpal tunnel syndrome, or more systemic issues like diabetes, which affects nerve health. It could also be a sign of vitamin B12 deficiency.  These could be harmless bruises from trauma, but if unexplained, a dark line under the nail could point to melanoma, a type of skin cancer. It's something that should be evaluated quickly.  A sudden decline in grip strength can be a sign of nerve problems, muscle wasting, or even early rheumatoid arthritis. It can also reflect overall decline in physical health, especially in older adults.  Paying attention to persistent or unusual changes in the hands can help in early detection and timely management of several health conditions. headline: These Supplements May Be Harming Your Kidneys
content: Supplements can be harmful to the kidneys, especially when taken in excess or without proper medical guidance. The kidneys are responsible for filtering waste and toxins from the blood, and certain supplements can overburden this system, leading to damage or worsening existing kidney conditions. Some supplements contain substances that are directly toxic to the kidneys, while others can interfere with medications, alter fluid and electrolyte balance, or contribute to the formation of kidney stones. Read on as we share a list of supplements that might be harming your kidneys.   Vitamin D is essential for bone health and immune function, but excessive intake can raise calcium levels in the blood. This condition, called hypercalcemia, can strain the kidneys and lead to the formation of calcium-based kidney stones. Prolonged high calcium levels may also cause calcification in kidney tissues, impairing their function.  Common among athletes and bodybuilders, creatine is used to enhance muscle performance. However, high doses or prolonged use can stress the kidneys by increasing the amount of creatinine, a waste product that kidneys must filter. In people with existing kidney conditions, creatine can accelerate damage.  Protein is essential, but overconsumption especially through supplements can overwork the kidneys. Excess protein increases the nitrogen load in the blood, which the kidneys must excrete. This can lead to glomerular hyper-filtration and, over time, may contribute to kidney damage, especially in people with underlying kidney disease.  Willow bark and similar herbal supplements contain salicylates, similar to aspirin and other non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). These can reduce blood flow to the kidneys and interfere with their ability to regulate salt and water balance, potentially leading to acute kidney injury, especially when used frequently or in combination with dehydration.  While vitamin C is water-soluble and generally considered safe, large doses (over 2,000 mg/day) can increase oxalate production in the body. Oxalate can bind with calcium to form crystals, which may accumulate in the kidneys as stones. Chronic overuse of vitamin C supplements has been linked to oxalate nephropathy, a serious kidney condition.  Used for digestive issues and adrenal fatigue, licorice root contains glycyrrhizin, which can lead to elevated blood pressure and low potassium levels, a condition known as hypokalaemia. These effects can strain kidney function, especially in people with pre-existing heart or kidney conditions. Chronic use has been associated with fluid retention and electrolyte imbalances that impair renal health.  While magnesium is vital for muscle and nerve function, taking too much, especially in supplement form can be harmful, particularly in people with reduced kidney function. Healthy kidneys usually excrete excess magnesium, but when they are impaired, magnesium can accumulate in the body, causing symptoms like nausea, low blood pressure, and, in severe cases, kidney toxicity or even cardiac arrest.  Even healthy individuals may be at risk if they use high doses over a prolonged period or combine multiple supplements without supervision. headline: 7 Long-Term Health Risks Of Ultra-Processed Foods
content: Ultra-processed foods, those high in artificial additives, refined sugars, saturated fats, and preservatives, have become a convenient part of modern diets. From packaged snacks to sugary drinks, these foods are everywhere. However, the long-term health consequences are alarming. According to a 2023 report by the World Health Organisation (WHO), diets rich in ultra-processed foods are linked to a range of chronic conditions including obesity, type 2 diabetes, and heart disease. The issue isn't just about empty calories, it's about the chemical processing that strips food of its natural nutritional value and may harm your body over time. Here's what you need to know. Ultra-processed foods often contain high levels of sugar, unhealthy fats, sodium, and chemical additives that can disrupt metabolic health. They are designed for shelf life and taste, not nutrition. As per Harvard Health and WHO, consistent consumption of such foods can trigger inflammation, hormone imbalance, and poor gut health, increasing your risk of lifestyle diseases and even some cancers over time. Let's explore the science behind this fermented favourite. With packed itineraries and limited access to clean facilities, hygiene can often take a back seat. Here are 7 essential hygiene tips to help you stay healthy and safe while travelling. Ultra-processed foods are calorie-dense and nutrient-poor. They promote overeating due to their addictive combinations of sugar, salt, and fat. These foods also bypass normal satiety signals, leading to weight gain. A study published in Cell Metabolism (2019) found that people who ate ultra-processed foods consumed 500 more calories daily compared to those eating whole foods, significantly increasing their risk of obesity. The high glycemic index of ultra-processed foods spikes blood sugar levels rapidly. Over time, this can lead to insulin resistance and eventually type 2 diabetes. The British Medical Journal (BMJ) published findings indicating a 12% higher risk of diabetes among individuals who frequently consumed ultra-processed items, including sugary drinks, refined cereals, and packaged desserts. High sodium and trans fat content in ultra-processed foods can elevate blood pressure and cholesterol levels. This significantly increases the risk of cardiovascular diseases. The American Heart Association warns that even moderate consumption of these foods may contribute to arterial plaque buildup and hypertension, particularly in middle-aged adults. Emerging evidence links frequent intake of ultra-processed foods to an elevated cancer risk. A French study in The BMJ found that a 10% increase in ultra-processed food consumption was associated with a 12% higher risk of cancer. Additives like emulsifiers, nitrates, and artificial sweeteners may disrupt gut microbiota and promote carcinogenic activity. Ultra-processed foods are low in fibre and high in chemical additives that can damage the gut lining. They disturb the natural balance of healthy bacteria, leading to issues like bloating, constipation, or even inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD). A healthy gut is vital for immune and mental health, and long-term exposure to these foods can compromise both. Research suggests a correlation between ultra-processed food consumption and mood disorders such as depression and anxiety. A study in Public Health Nutrition linked these diets with a 30% increase in the likelihood of experiencing depression. These foods lack essential nutrients like B-vitamins and omega-3 fatty acids, which support brain function. A large-scale Spanish cohort study concluded that those who consumed more than four servings of ultra-processed foods per day had a 62% higher risk of all-cause mortality. Regular intake of these foods affects multiple systems in the body, metabolic, cardiovascular, and immune, leading to accelerated aging and disease vulnerability. Ultra-processed foods may offer convenience, but the long-term health risks are far too significant to ignore. From metabolic dysfunction to increased cancer and mortality risks, their impact spans the entire body. Reducing intake and choosing whole, minimally processed foods can drastically improve overall health. As always, consult your doctor or a dietitian for personalised dietary guidance.
